segments.text: This is August the 10th and sitting in the Harrington Tower interviewing Dr. Brian Cole about his experiences here, first as a graduate student and then as a faculty member.
Brian, introduce yourself to anyone who may listen or read the transcript of this tape.
background where'd you grow up family high school education experience before you came to A&M okay I was I'm a native Texan born in Wichita Falls and
Moved to Dallas for a couple of years and then started public schools in Marlin, Texas, just 60 miles north of College Station.
And so I have fond childhood memories of A&M back during when it was its traditional self.
And my dad was a football nut, literally.
And I can remember as a child on those few occasions where there would be a noon game here that I would come down with my dad and we would go to the game here until about halftime.
And then we would leave and drive to Waco for a three o'clock game at Waco and stay there till about halftime and then drive to Fort Worth or to Dallas to catch a TCU or SMU game that evening.
Now that didn't happen a lot because of scheduling, but it kind of gives you a sense of my dad's love for football, and of course I enjoyed A&M at that time.
Graduated from Marlin High School in 1962.
Had the opportunity to be student body president there, and really enjoyed my school years there.
Worked all through high school.
I had the privilege of being appointed to West Point by then Congressman Pogue, who was chairman of the House Ag Committee.
It was interesting because A&M had been one of the schools that I considered, but I didn't want to go there at the time because it was all male.
Of course, West Point was all male, too, but had a little bit different flavor, so I went there.
I had to work pretty hard to be successful academically there as well as otherwise, but it was a great experience.
I had the honor of being
commander of the company A-1 my senior year, which meant that as A-1, we always led all the parades and all the march-ons to the Army-Navy game and all that kind of stuff.
So it was kind of neat.
Marching in General MacArthur's funeral procession in New York City when he died.
So just lots of opportunities, lots of leadership exposure
And that famous speech that he made at West Point.
Was the spring before I went in.
It was May of 62.
But it still had such an impact that when we got there as plebes that summer, upperclassmen were still talking about it, I mean, and with some emotion in their voice.
So we knew that it was quite something to, and of course I've heard it a hundred times in different situations over time.
Did West Point outfits have nicknames like Aggie outfits?
Did A-1 have a nickname?
Not really.
Well, some did.
But they were usually tied to the alphabet.
But A-1 did not have one.
Most did not.
Most did not.
Graduated from West Point in 66 and was commissioned in the artillery at the time.
I had the opportunity to go to airborne and ranger school, and then we went to Europe where I was stationed with a Hawk battery about 17 miles from the Czech border.
And that was a really good experience, had a lot of great NCOs who educated me and learned me, as we might say.

Spent a year there, then got reassigned to Bad Kreuznach, Germany, to the 8th Infantry Division, where I moved in and took over the, moved in the personnel realm and took over the personnel services division for the, for the infantry division.
Was there about eight months and then got curtailed as most everyone else was during that time to come back to Vietnam Went to language school.
So the Ferris School and then a year in Vietnam And then back for about six months at Fort Hood and then selected to come out of the service at that time and came back to
graduate school, initially to go into public school administration.
What year was this?
This was 1970.
Kind of serendipitous, or maybe that's not the correct word, but I came back from Vietnam in March of 70, and was on leave for a couple of weeks there until I reported into Fort Hood.
So during that time, had come down to A&M to talk to the faculty here about my application and assistantship.
And I came, and it just so happened that that was the week that Earl Rutter had died,
And he was lying in state in the systems building and had an occasion to sort of get a flavor because of that, of the impact that General Rudder had had.
Did you walk over?
I actually went over and described.
Feelings, sentiments that you experienced?
Well, you could tell that there was a very distinct specialness.
It was almost like
almost like being in the Capitol building in Washington when someone of national stature is lying in state.
Members of the Cadet Corps, from the different outfits, were standing around, much as they do in the Capitol building, from the different services.
And each of the military departments were represented from the Cadet Corps.
Of course, all the flags on campus were at half-mast.
It was a very somber time.
But you had a sense that something special was occurring.
And then after I got out in August, we moved here in August of 1970.
And you have children at this point?
I had one son, and Keith at that time was two years old, and came back to begin master's work in educational administration.
Now, why did you pick A&M instead of some other institution?
Well, I had made application to A&M and to Baylor,
We wanted to be close to home, and A&M offered me the graduate assistantship.
And you thought at that time your career goal was?
Was public school administration.
And so I came back and began working on that.
I had to complete my teacher certification at the time under the old Jamison Act.
And I had like 60 hours in math and more than enough hours in physics, and so my teaching fields were math and physics.
But I remember being in the fourth floor of the academic building, and I'd been four years since I'd done any, you know, real math.
And Dr. Chewy for the math department was my prof, and it was an advanced calculus class that I really didn't need.
I was just doing it for getting back.
And he was one of these guys that would write with one hand and erase with the other.

And, you know, there were all these young undergraduate, because it was not a graduate-level course, it was a 400-level course, and there was all these undergraduate kids just humming along, doing fine.
And I knew that even though I was only about four or five years old of these kids, that something had transpired during that time.
So...
But we made it through.
I see.
Did you have to take Texas government?
Oh, yes.
That's part of the deal.
Texas government and Texas history.
Actually, I took the Texas government, but I tested out of the Texas history.
But toward the end of that year, Dr. Frank Hubert, who was the dean of the College of Education at that time, for some reason...

had noticed me or heard about me or whatever and just one day out of the clear blue in about April he calls me over to his office and of course you know I'm a little antsy about that because Dr. Hubert even then had a reputation Haskell as you are well aware so I go over and sit there and Dr. Hubert said
You know, one of the things I've done over the years is to try to identify promising graduate students and to bring them into my office as assistant to the dean while they work on their doctorate.
And I wondered if you might be interested in doing that.
And this is your first year?
This is about, this is the end of my first year.
Now what was, what was your, describe
your first impression of him as a person?
Well, pretty intimidating.
Someone that you knew was serious
someone who had a tremendous intellect, someone who cared deeply about education, and someone who, by their very nature, you did not want to disappoint.
and who instilled a lot of confidence by his expression of his confidence in you.
Did you ever later learn who it was that helped him identify you?
No, my guess is it would probably be Paul Hensarling.
I was Paul's graduate assistant.
And of course, Paul and Frank had had a long professional association.
Describe Dr. Henseling and your work for him.
OK.
He was a rather unique guy.
Dr. Henseling had been superintendent at Orange for some period of time.
And I don't know exactly when he actually came to A&M, but he was one of the professors in the Department of Education Administration.
And Dr. Hensheling had had a voice problem, a physical voice problem.
At some point, I don't remember exactly when, but it caused him to talk rather low and with an airy kind of forced speech.
But he didn't let that get in his way.
And he was a guy that had very high expectations and basically would lay out, and these are the things I want you to do, and then, you know, you go forth and do.
And had a pretty close relationship because we didn't have separate offices back then, and so I actually had a table right there in his office.
Was he the chairman?
No, Hal Hawkins was the chair at that time.
Other faculty members were Les Richardson, Tim Stennett, and it was a fairly small department, and Hal.
But Dr. Henshling was the senior man in years?
Yes, yes, yes.
And your duties for him?
Doing research, some background publication work.

He was working primarily in the area of school services, support services, auxiliary services we might call them, and annually updated a sort of a series of readings and texts, so I did some work on that.

One of my big responsibilities was to do all the logistical preparation for the administrative leadership, what we called the June Conference back then, which was an annual conference for school administrators from all over the state, mostly superintendents and a few principals.
And we'd have 400 or 500 folks come in for that.
And had a big reputation.
Over the years, it had developed sort of a traditional history of typical things that would go on.
And so it was as much a fellowship time for school administrators as it was for professional development.
And so I did all the logistics work for that.
For Dr. Hensley?
For Dr. Hensley, yes.
In that first year?
In that first year, right.
That was quite a bit of time devoted toward that activity.
And so then in the spring of that first year, you have this conversation with Dr. Hubert, and then follow next what, he gives you an assignment?
Well, he asked me first if I wanted to do it, and he said the plan would be, he said Jerry Vinson at the time was the assistant to the dean.
And Jerry was about a year out from finishing.
And Dr. Hewitt said, if you're interested, what I'd like to do is, beginning in September, is for you to come over and be a graduate assistant and sort of understudy Jerry.
And then when he graduates summer of 72, then if everything works out, then you'd become assistant.
Do you remember what the compensation was?
Well, as a GA, it was about, I have a later interesting story about that, but as a GA, it was about three and a quarter a month, I think, as I recall.
And what were you and your family living on?
Well, that, plus I had the GI Bill.
Oh, I forgot, sure.
Plus, my wife was working as a teacher's aide at Snook.
And just as an interesting aside, one of her also duties was to sponsor the pep squad at Snook.
And, of course, this was back in the early 70s during their heyday of being the Class B basketball powerhouse in the state.
Mm-hmm.
And I can remember on more than one occasion of driving over to Austin to watch the state finals, one in particular.
Coincidentally, Phil Graham's first wife was a teacher for whom my wife was an aide, Sherry Graham.
And I can remember the state finals at Gregory Gym at UT, and Phil was right in front of me.
And, of course, this was early 70s when he was like an assistant professor of economics.
And suffice it to say that Phil got into the game.
I mean, I had two shows going on.
One was the game and one was Phil.
Because if the ref made any call whatsoever that he felt was inappropriate, I mean, he was right in their face.
It was pretty interesting, you know.
Let me turn this off.
All right.
And so you began then?
Began that fall.
Now, meanwhile, you're taking a full course load.
One other thing, I remained active in the Army Reserve.
And that played a rather important role then throughout the rest of my time.
Describe that first year or two.
What was a typical week?
What all were you doing?
Well, taking how many hours?
In that fall, in that fall I was taking 12 hours, more than a full load.
I was working 20 hours a week as a graduate assistant.

My wife was working full time, plus we were juggling our young son, because again, in the later fall, when basketball season really began, and she had to go to the pep squad, sometimes it was one or two o'clock in the morning before they got back in, so I'd have to go and wake Keith up and go out and get all that kind of stuff.
And then, at least once a month, I was doing a weekend for the reserve.
And where were you all living?
We were living in the Bryan Orms apartments down on South College for our first year.
Do you remember what the rent was?
I try to put in things like this as a kind of a barometer.
No, but I can give you another barometer.
Okay.

Because after that first year, and we, I made the decision then, let me back up, because when Dr. Hubert asked me if I wanted to become his assistant dean, at that time, professionally, I really had to decide did I want to stay public school or go higher ed.
I had realized during the course of that first year that I really felt like I might be able to contribute better in higher ed than in public school.
So it helped make that decision.
But once we decided to stay, then, and with Keith growing up, we decided, well, if we're going to be here four years, we need to try to find the little house.
And so in the
Let's see, I guess it was around January.
Yeah, it was during the Christmas break of my first year with Dr. Huber.
that we seriously began looking for a little house.
We found a little house over on Eagle Pass, which is off of Texas.
And there's a wonderful little two-bedroom house built in 1933.
And the lady who lived in it was Mrs. Schmidt.
And her husband, back in the 40s, had been the dean of the vet school.
And she was a wonderful, wonderful lady.
And we really enjoyed visiting her.
And even after we bought her place, frequently, about every Sunday afternoon for several months, she would drive by and stop in for a few minutes.
And of course, we welcomed to have her.
But it was a wonderful little place to be a young graduate student and so forth.
What was the price on that?
Well, that was what I was going to tell you.
The price of the house was $17,000.
And Wanda, my wife, to this day, uh, kids me about remembering when we signed those papers that I was literally white as a sheet obligating myself to that kind of, uh, debt, you know.
Uh, and, uh, so it was a great little place.
It had a nice backyard.
It was a nice neighborhood during the time, nice neighbors and, and so forth.
But, uh,

so it was uh it was doing all those things of you know family and school and working and reserve and all that uh so you began with dr hubert then in the fall of fall of uh 71 71 and also another graduate assistant in the office at that time was barry thompson
who subsequently became, obviously, chancellor of the A&M system.
And Barry was also, Hubert had worked out a deal with Barry.
He was doing his residency, and so he was a graduate assistant, but he was also at least part-time superintending at Waco ISD at that time.
And so Barry and I developed, began the development there of a lifetime friendship and professional association, which has been very good all these years.
And so as it turned out, Jerry Vincent, who was the assistant to the dean,
Got a job offer prematurely, it's not really premature, unexpectedly, to be the director of the Mahea State School.
Well, he was ABD at that point.
Man, I don't know, I was not privy to exactly what Hubert suggested to him, but Jerry decided to take that.
which meant that he was leaving toward the end of January of 73.
No, 72, yeah, because I started in the fall of 71, which sort of upped my ante on moving into the assistant to the dean thing.
Well, my very first assignment as assistant to the dean was, Hubert had, and I'd been working on it somewhat, but Hubert had planned a faculty retreat at the flagship hotel in Galveston.
And so my responsibility was to lay all that on.
And I remember John Calhoun was invited down, and Dick , they came down as a part of that for presentations and so forth.
It was about a three-day retreat.
And I was just in the process of sort of moving into the assistant to the dean role at that time.

And I remember prior to going down there, Dr. Hubert had discussed with me that I would start at $8,100 working full-time as assistant to the dean, which, you know, compared to 300 bucks a month, that's pretty good stuff.
This will give you some flavor of Dr. Hubert.

Coming back after we'd come back from that conference, and I have another story to tell you about that in a minute, but coming back from that, after we got back, Dr. Hubert called me in and said, Brian,
He said, I want to tell you, that was the best conference that I've ever had.
And he said, I attribute that to your work.
He said, it was flawless, dah, dah, dah, dah, dah, dah.
And he said, what I'm going to do is we're going to raise your starting salary to $9,000.
Wow.
I thought, yeah, all right.
So that was a nice little deal right off the bat.
And the aside story I want to tell you, in driving back from Galveston after that conference, I was riding with Dr. Hubert.
And he had a Willie Nelson tape in the radio.
And Willie was singing Michelle.
And Dr. Hubert got this very nostalgic look on his face.
And after it was over, I said, Dr. Hubert, I said, that song seemed to mean something to you.
He said, well, let me tell you.
He said, back when I was at UT, I was working and going to school and all this.
And he said, a friend of mine approached me that they were putting a band together for the summer to play on a cruise ship to go to Europe.
And he said he won't know if I want to try out for the band.
So I thought about it and said, well, yeah, I guess I will.
And of course, he was primarily a woodwind person at that point.
And so he tried out for the band, but he didn't get it.
But about a week before the band left, I think it was the trumpet or cornet player got sick and couldn't go or what have you.
So his friend came to him and said, Hubert, can you play cornet?
He says, well, nobody can learn.
And so, in the space of a week, Dr. Hubert went to a pawn shop, got somebody's horn out of pawn, taught himself how to play the trumpet, and then played in that band on the cruise ship over.
They had some time in France while they were there, and while they were in France, he met a Michelle.
whom he obviously had some very fond memories about.
That's as far as I know.
I had not heard that part of it before.
But then they then play on the way back.
They get back, and because of his financial straitness at the time, he then takes the horn back to that pawn shop and gets his money back.
I think that's a great story.
Oh, yes.
When you...
Started out did he describe your duties and how well did his description match the realities?
You were to be the assistant for what yeah basically for budgets administration Contracting grant activity we had at the time One two three four five
five secretaries in the dean's office.
They all reported to me.

In other words, I was sort of the office manager as well as, and then I was responsible for the college budgets and the administration of all of that, the administration of all the contracting grant accounts, all personnel actions, those kinds of things.
Physically, y'all were located?
Physically, we were in the west end of the academic library, the old library, on the first floor, where they've now remodeled all that that looks so nice.
Oh, in Cushing.
Cushing, yeah, west end of Cushing, right on the first floor there.
And the College of Education?
The dean's office.
Dean's office.
That's all that was there.
Yeah.
Who were the other professionals?
Lannis Hope was the associate dean for student affairs and Don Clark was the associate dean for research.
Describe them and their
their characteristics and their manner of.
Well, Landis was an educational psychologist.
He was a very interesting gentleman.
Extremely well read.
I think I must have read four books a week of all genre.
But at the time in the college, we had, I'll have to go back in a minute.
At the time in the college, we had maybe a few hundred students.
And so as associate dean for students, it was not a huge job, but he had other responsibilities.
I think it was a half-time appointment.
And then he was a half-time with the Ed Psych faculty.
But very sensitive, very much what you think of as a counselor type individual.
had had some interesting World War II experiences and sort of relived those on occasion.
Don Clark had come to A&M from the Midwest and had done work at Stout, I think.
I don't remember where his doctorate is from, but somewhere in the Midwest.
And Don had been fairly active in the contracting grant work, and so his role was primarily helping faculty through research and graduate programs.
Of course, it was a new, growing entity.
Now the key staff, the chief of the staff was Peggy Ritchie?
Yes.
Describe Peggy.
Well, Peggy was what one might think of when thinking of a

a woman who's been in an office for a long period of time, who knows her job backwards, forwards, and sideways, who has a wealth of information, and who people would go to with some regularity on a whole variety of issues.
